Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Cognitive Agents and Pedestrian Redevelopment Modeling

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cities across the country are trying to determine how to best deal with existing systems of transportation infrastructure while incorporating shifting views about public health, urban mobility, and environmental sustainability. In many locales, planners have proposed pedestrian-oriented redevelopment projects that would require a fundamental shift in the spatial organization of the city. This doctoral dissertation research project will enhance understanding of how structural changes to the urban environment would impact individual behaviors. The doctoral student will employ computational approaches to examine how individual perception and cognition of environmental features influences real-world decisions and behaviors. New insights will be provided regarding the theoretical and practical facets of urban behaviors via empirically driven cognitive models. The project will provide new information and insights for planners and policy makers, because it will address larger societal questions regarding the appropriate redesign of urban spaces in order to address larger environmental, economic, and public health issues. Findings of the project also will increase knowledge of how agent-based modeling can be used by the stakeholders and the public to evaluate the impacts of redevelopment on both individual citizens and the community at large. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

This project will approach pedestrian-oriented redevelopment from a computational, human-centered perspective, which will offer new insights into the multiple ways designed space is perceived and how those perceptions are translated into individual spatial behaviors. Pedestrian-oriented redevelopment is often understood to be a simple, solution-based approach to address larger structural and social issues of the city. Transforming existing street infrastructure is not a straightforward process, however, because of embedded automobile-oriented perspectives. This project will focus on three core questions: (1) How can data about individual differences regarding environmental cognition be used in the development of a pedestrian movement model? (2) How does the development of agent cognition aid in the credibility of real-world pedestrian movement models? (3) What key design variables in urban redevelopment projects emerge from cognitively driven pedestrian movement models? The doctoral student will use data generated from psychometric tests of environmental cognition as he develops agent-based spatial models. The outputs of the models will provide new information regarding how small changes to the urban environment could impact real-world decision making and behaviors. Examining and modeling individual cognitive processes in urban spaces will provide a rigorous, data-driven approach to answer questions both about individual agency as well as about the structure of the planned urban environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant, Cognitive Agents and Pedestrian Redevelopment Modeling, investigated the role of cognition and environmental behavior in the creation and use of agent-based pedestrian models. Agent -based models are a relatively new type of modeling, built from the bottom-up where individual entities enact a series of behaviors and local interactions across a virtual environment. The cumulative effect of all these small interactions can produce unexpected and not easily reducible results, highlighting the importance of looking at the individuals within a system. Agent-based models are especially valuable in understanding pedestrian behavior, as pedestrians differ both in speed, decision-making, flexibility, and social processes compared to other forms of transportation.

This research found that explicitly focusing on the cognitive aspects of pedestrian behavior, such as navigation strategy, perception of the environment, and locational awareness provides a scientifically robust and empirically valid way to model the pedestrian, allowing the model to capture both individual agency and system-wide results. This approach is especially valuable in transportation and urban planning discourses, as it provides a lens in which to view individual pedestrians in an urban system and allows for deeper engagements with the idea of urban walkability.

As city management decisions become more data driven, it is critically important to reevaluate how the pedestrian is commonly represented, what underlying assumptions are built into the pedestrian, and how that directs our vision of walkable neighborhoods. Commonly, the pedestrian is embedded with utilitarian behaviors that rely on configurational spatial ontologies, fixed environmental affordances, and hard urban materiality. The research uses cognitive testing and observed environmental behavior to illustrates how orthodox urban and transportation planning practices often rely of ordered urban spaces in which rational pedestrians make spatiotemporal assessments to maximize efficiency. This heavily structured framing of urban transportation spaces essentially renders the pedestrian as a slower moving version of the private automobile and negates all the unique moments that occur in the act of walking itself.

This research contributed to the field of geography, urban design, transportation planning, and agent-based modeling with a series of three peer-reviewed papers, currently under review. The first introduces a theoretical framework to understand and represent the pedestrian agent in planning and transportation discourses. The second details an innovative methodology for the development and parameterization of agents within a model framework, illustrating how front end validation of human entities through psychometric and behavioral test creates ecologically valid simulation models. The third turns attention to a case study of transportation redevelopment in Eugene, Oregon, illustrating how a ecologically valid model of pedestrian movements produces a set of results not captured by traditional analysis.

The research was productive from an educational and community outreach perspective. During the course of the study, three undergraduate research assistants helped with data collection, research design, analysis, and data visualization. The project also involved members of the local community and the model results were disseminated at a neighborhood forum about the redevelopment project, allowing concerned citizens the opportunity to use the model and interpret the results based on their individual experiences. In the end, the research and public dissemination of the model helped give voice to citizens in a unique way, providing a data-driven tool to help support arguments and deepening understandings of the neighborhood system to the people who reside within it.
